question: What makes combinations more effective than throwing single punches?
explanation: The key to effective combinations is the continuous rotation from left to right (and right to left). As Jordan explains: 'Every single punch links into the next one... the jab is what starts it all and that's coming from this position to this position. This bit of rotation can turn my body through nearly 180 degrees to line up my cross.' Each punch naturally flows into the next when you maintain this rotational axis.

options.text: Each punch sets up the next through continuous body rotation from left to right
Stacking multiple fast punches overwhelms your opponent's guard through sheer volume
Throwing in sequence builds momentum so each punch carries significantly more force
Combinations target the same spot repeatedly which breaks down the defensive guard

question: Your training partner says your cross is 'telegraphed' and they can see it coming. What should you check first?
explanation: Telegraphing happens when you give visual cues before the punch: pulling the hand back, tensing the shoulder, or doing a 'bow and arrow' motion. The punch should initiate from the hips with the arm staying relaxed until extension. The arm follows the body, not the other way around.

options.text: Whether you're pulling your arm back or tensing your shoulder before throwing
Whether you're generating enough hip rotation to deliver full power through the cross
Whether your rear foot is pivoting far enough to commit your full bodyweight forward
Whether your front hand is dropping low enough to clear a clean path for the cross

question: Which defensive technique is being demonstrated in this image?
explanation: The CATCH is performed by turning your rear hand outward to meet an incoming jab with a little pressure. It's specifically effective against jabs because they carry less power. Unlike a parry which redirects the punch, the catch stops it in place. Your catch hand mirrors the opponent's punch side.

options.text: Parry - redirecting the punch to the side
Catch - absorbing the punch with a firm rear palm
Full Block - covering with both hands on the face
Slip - dropping your head off the center line

question: When would you use a PARRY instead of a CATCH?
explanation: The PARRY redirects punches off-course rather than stopping them. This is crucial for power shots like the cross - just turning your hand (catch) won't stop a hard cross from getting through. With a parry, you rotate slightly and tap the punch aside, taking it off course. This also leaves the opponent off-balance and open for counters. Catches work for jabs because they carry less power.

options.text: Against a jab, because the jab's speed requires a deflection rather than absorbing the full impact
Against a cross, because redirecting a power shot is more effective than trying to stop it
Against hooks, because sweeping the punch inward lets you redirect its full circular trajectory
Against body shots, because tapping the punch downward protects both the liver and the floating ribs

question: During sparring, body shots keep landing on your liver and ribs. What should you focus on to fix this?
explanation: Body shot defense relies on your ELBOWS covering your liver and spleen - not your hands. Key adjustments: (1) Keep elbows tucked tight against your body, (2) Concave your stomach inward to make a smaller target, (3) Lean SLIGHTLY into incoming body shots so your elbow absorbs more impact. If elbows are flared out, you have to move them further to block. Good shape = easy body defense.

options.text: Drop your hands to waist level and use your forearms to shield the liver and the ribs
Keep elbows tucked, concave your stomach, and lean slightly into body shots
Step back out of range each time they load up to make their body shots fall short
Stay aggressive and throw fast counter punches so they can't set up their body attacks

question: A boxer is slipping punches but keeps getting hit anyway. Looking at their technique, they're bending forward at the WAIST instead of using hip rotation. What's the main problem with this?
explanation: When you bend at the waist instead of rotating your hips and using your legs, you shift your weight forward uncontrollably. This destroys your balance, makes it nearly impossible to return to guard quickly, and leaves you unable to throw effective counters. Proper slipping uses hip rotation with a slight shoulder dip while maintaining the 60% back foot weight distribution.

options.text: Their chin becomes exposed by drifting past the guard line
They lose balance and can't counter effectively
The slipping motion becomes telegraphed to the opponent
Their rear guard hand naturally drops away from the chin

question: When slipping a jab from an orthodox opponent (you're also orthodox), why should you slip to the OUTSIDE (your left) rather than to the inside?
explanation: When you slip a jab to the outside (your left vs an orthodox opponent), you move AWAY from their rear hand (the cross). If you slipped inside, you'd be moving directly into the path of their power punch. The same principle applies in reverse when slipping their cross - you slip to your right to avoid their follow-up jab.

options.text: Slipping outside uses your natural hip rotation to accelerate the movement
Slipping outside moves you away from their power hand (the cross)
Your lead shoulder covers your chin more effectively when you slip outside
Slipping outside lines up your rear hand for a direct counter to their body

question: What's the key difference between a ROLL and a WEAVE?
explanation: The key mechanical difference is hip engagement. When rolling, you use leg bend and hip rotation while keeping your torso relatively upright. When weaving (like Mayweather), you bend more at the hips, bringing your head forward and down before coming up on the other side. Weaving covers more distance forward but requires more flexibility and timing.

options.text: A roll uses more knee bend, a weave uses more hip bend forward
A roll keeps your head still, a weave moves it side to side
A roll transfers weight back, a weave shifts it to the front
A roll drops your eye level lower, a weave keeps eyes level

question: Look at the diagram showing two boxers. Based on the distance between them (feet almost in line, guards nearly touching), what range are they fighting at?
explanation: This is mid-range. At mid-range, your feet are almost in line with your opponent's, and you throw hooks where your palms face downward. If the palm faces toward you, that's close range. If it faces outward, that's long range. Mid-range requires constant head movement and hand defenses rather than foot defenses.

options.text: Out of range - beyond the reach of any straight punches
Long range - where only jabs can reach the target cleanly
Mid range - hooks with palms facing down land effectively
Short range - close enough for uppercuts and clinch work

question: Why is controlling distance (range management) considered one of the most important skills in boxing?
explanation: Range management determines everything in boxing. At each range, different punches become effective - jabs at long range, hooks at mid range, uppercuts at short range. Being out of range means you're safe but can't attack. Understanding range lets you choose when to engage and with which weapons, while knowing when you're vulnerable. Both tall and short fighters need range management - taller fighters to keep opponents at distance, shorter fighters to close the gap.

options.text: It controls the tempo and forces your opponent to constantly adjust their rhythm and approach
It determines which punches can land effectively and when you're safe from attack
It mainly benefits taller fighters who use their reach to keep opponents at jab-length distance
It reduces how much energy you spend on footwork so you can put more power into your punches

question: You keep getting caught flat-footed during sparring and can't react quickly to your opponent's attacks. What should you work on?
explanation: Being 'light on your feet' comes from strong feet and tendons, built through skipping, running, and practice. Transfer your weight between the balls of your feet constantly - this lets you change position quickly. The Maasai tribe can jump incredibly high using just their plantar fascia, and boxers use similar principles to stay mobile and reactive.

options.text: Bouncing - stay on the balls of your feet and build foot strength through skipping
Increase your punch output with high-volume combinations to keep opponents on their back foot
Close the distance and fight at short range so quick reactions matter less in the exchange
Strengthen your upper body guard to absorb shots because movement is secondary to solid defense

question: When throwing a hook to the body, which palm orientation is correct?
explanation: For body hooks, the palm should face UPWARD with the wrist kinked. This allows the knuckles to dig up under the ribs (targeting the liver or spleen) for maximum damage. A flat or downward-facing palm can't achieve this angle and reduces effectiveness significantly.

options.text: Palm facing downward with the elbow at a tight ninety degrees
Palm facing upward with a kinked wrist to dig under the ribs
Palm facing inward with the thumb pointing directly upward
Palm facing outward with the wrist fully locked and straight

question: You throw lead hooks but constantly feel off-balance and find yourself stumbling forward. What's the most likely cause?
explanation: Falling forward on the lead hook is a SUPER common mistake caused by pushing weight toward your knuckles instead of pulling backward. This removes all power and resistance behind the punch. Think of a hammer thrower - they pull BACK to whip the hammer around. Your knuckles should whip forward while your weight stays back or transfers rearward.

options.text: Your stance is too narrow which limits the base of support you need for rotational hook mechanics
You're transferring weight FORWARD instead of backward - moving your axis toward your knuckles
You're not pivoting your lead foot far enough to engage full hip rotation and transfer the energy properly
You're snapping the hook too fast which whips your shoulder forward before your hips can stabilize

question: Which image shows correct jab technique at full extension?
explanation: At full jab extension, your shoulder should come up to protect your chin, you should be looking down your arm at the target, elbow locked out, and palm facing down. This creates both protection and maximum reach.

options.text: Arm extended with the shoulder dropped, chin left exposed
Arm extended, shoulder raised to chin, looking down the arm
Arm slightly bent at elbow with fist held at chin level
Arm fully locked out with the palm rotated facing upward

question: Your punches feel 'arm-heavy' with no snap. You notice your back heel stays planted and your hips barely move. What should you fix first?
explanation: The fix is rotation, starting from your back foot. Your spine is your axis of rotation—pivot on the ball of your back foot, which turns your knee, which turns your hip to face perpendicular to your opponent. This rotation should go through nearly 180 degrees (from side-on to facing forward). Keep your head still as the axis point while your body rotates around it. Without this hip rotation, you're just arm-punching and missing the entire kinetic chain.

options.text: Drive power from your rear shoulder by tensing your arm muscles through the punch
Pivot on the ball of your back foot and rotate your hips to face the target
Shift your weight onto your front foot and lean your torso toward the target
Increase arm speed by snapping the elbow faster to generate more impact force

question: You notice you keep getting pushed off balance when you throw punches, especially combinations. What's most likely wrong with your stance?
explanation: Balance comes from how you plant your feet. Oliver uses the analogy: 'Boxing as though your feet are stuck in mud. If your feet are stuck in mud, no matter how hard or how much power or speed you put into a punch, you're not going to fall off balance because your feet are fixed to the ground.' The key is to push backwards with your front foot and forwards with your back foot simultaneously, creating opposing forces that keep you stable.

options.text: You're not gripping the ground with your feet and creating stability between them
You're loading too much weight onto your front foot which stops your rear leg from anchoring
Your stance is too wide which prevents the fast hip rotation needed for quick combinations
You're extending your punches too far past the centerline and overreaching on every shot

question: Looking at this diagram showing a boxer with their weight too far forward - what specific problem does this create?
explanation: When weight is too far forward, your head moves into danger. As Oliver explains: 'It's very easy to be front foot dominant like this, leaning over that front foot, getting your head in range where it can get smacked around.' The solution is to get your weight back while using proper rotation to still reach the same distance. Your head stays safe, but your punches can still land.

options.text: It reduces the arc on your hooks because your arm can't fully rotate from there
Your head is in range where it can get hit, and you're easier to push off balance
Your rear cross travels a longer distance which telegraphs the punch to opponents
Your front knee absorbs too much pressure which wears down your legs over rounds

question: Why is relaxation so important in your boxing stance and when throwing punches?
explanation: Oliver explains the anatomy: 'If you didn't know, your muscles move your skeleton. When we're punching, it wouldn't be advantageous to tense my bicep because it's doing the opposing contraction - it's gonna be harder for me to extend my arm.' Tension before a punch acts like a brake. You need relaxation UNTIL the moment of impact, then you tense to create a solid connection. It's 'relaxation to tension, not tension to relaxation.'

options.text: Tension in your arms slows down your punches because contracted muscles resist the extension
Staying relaxed conserves stamina in your shoulders so you can maintain a high guard for longer rounds
A relaxed stance lowers your center of gravity and makes it much harder for opponents to push you backward
Relaxation helps your footwork stay smooth so you can transition between offensive and defensive positions

question: What's wrong with this uppercut?
context: The boxer drops their arm way down and back before throwing the uppercut.
explanation: Dropping your arm all the way back is a 'super common mistake' that telegraphs your punch. Your opponent sees it coming. The arm only needs to drop to about 90 degrees at the elbow - the power comes from body rotation, not from winding up your arm.

options.text: They're telegraphing the punch by winding up too much
The arm needs to load deeper to build up more power
Their feet are too narrow for effective body rotation
They should track their fist to improve punch accuracy
